title: 108_s2790
content: The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" allows for the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications. The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" enables the Secretary of the Interior to issue a certificate of bidding rights to holders of withdrawn coal preference right lease applications. The Mineral Leasing Act allows for the relinquishment of coal preference lease applications without further adjudication by the Secretary. SEC. 3. METHOD FOR DETERMINING FAIR MARKET VALUE. The section applies to issuing a certificate of bidding rights under section 4(a)(2) and determines the fair market value of coal reserves for withdrawn lease applications through a panel established by the Secretary. A panel will determine the fair market value of coal reserves for withdrawn lease applications, composed of 3 representatives appointed by the Secretary, the lease holder, and the Governor of New Mexico. The Secretary will contract a mineral appraiser to determine the fair market value of a coal reserve for withdrawn lease applications. The panel may supplement information provided to them as needed, and a determination must be made within 75 days of the panel's establishment. The panel, established by the Secretary, will determine the fair market value of a coal reserve for withdrawn lease applications. SEC. 4. ISSUANCE OF PATENTS TO RELINQUISHED PREFERENCE RIGHT LEASE APPLICATIONS. The Secretary must issue patents to the Navajo Nation for land, including the mineral estate, within 120 days after the withdrawal of a coal preference right lease application, in satisfaction of the right to select land in New Mexico under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974. The Secretary must issue patents to the Navajo Nation for land, including the mineral estate, within 120 days after the withdrawal of a coal preference right lease application, in satisfaction of the right to select land in New Mexico under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974. Additionally, the Secretary is required to facilitate land consolidation and mineral development in northwest New Mexico by issuing a certificate of bidding rights based on fair market value, with these duties being enforceable in a mandamus proceeding. SEC. 5. USE OF EXCHANGE BIDDING RIGHTS. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) can be transferred in whole or in part and used as a monetary credit by the holder. The Secretary may establish procedures for notice of transfer and accountings of holders. The certificate of bidding rights can be used as a monetary credit by the holder against rentals, royalties, and bonus payments payable to the Secretary under Federal coal leases. Transfers of the certificate can be made in whole or in part, with procedures established by the Secretary for notice of transfer and accountings of holders. When a certificate of bidding rights is used as a monetary credit for a Federal coal lease payment, the holder can apply it to 50% of the amount due, with the remaining 50% to be paid in cash or cash equivalent. The holder of a certificate of bidding rights for a Federal coal lease payment can use it to cover 50% of the amount due, with the remaining 50% to be paid in cash. The cash portion will be distributed to the State where the lease is located and treated as a redistribution under the Mineral Leasing Act. 50% of the payment for a Federal coal lease can be covered using a certificate of bidding rights, with the remaining 50% to be paid in cash. The cash portion will be redistributed to the Reclamation and Miscellaneous Receipts accounts in the Treasury.
